title: The £20bn question: How will the Government kick-start regions like the North East?
text:
Chi Onwurah, Labour MP for Newcastle Central at the Labour Party North Regional Conference (Photo: Ian Forsyth/Getty Images) Share Get   Thank you for subscribing!   
Major investment in skills and innovation is needed if regions such as the North East are to succeed in a post-Brexit world, an MP has said. 
The stark warning comes after a report published by Sheffield Hallam University this week revealed that the UK is around £20bn a year worse off as a result of a decades long de-industrialisation strategy. 
And Newcastle Central’s Labour MP Chi Onwurah has urged the Government to work to readdress this balance. 
Speaking in a House of Commons debate on Wednesday, she said: “Brexit Britain faces a choice, an industrial strategy that invests in innovation to deliver smart, sustainable and shared growth or the slashing of wages, rights and corporate responsibilities in a race to the bottom. 
“Sunday’s report from Sheffield Hallam University put the price of the last Tory Government’s disastrous de-industrialisation strategy at £20bn a year today. 
“Will the Minister stop prevaricating and set out how he will invest in skills, research capacity and infrastructure to stimulate innovation in our great industrial regions?” Read More Nissan investment shows Brexit can work - but what did we offer in return? 
The report - Jobs, Welfare and Austerity - found that the highest incapacity claimant rates were in places such as the South Wales Valleys, the North East, Merseyside and Clydeside. 
In contrast, the incapacity claimant rate in much of the South and East of England, especially outside London, is modest. 
In effect, the report argues: “Communities in older industrial Britain are being meted out punishment in the form of welfare cuts for the destruction wrought to their industrial base.”
